author: By Alex Traub
title: A Reporter Striking Universal Chords
description: The reporter Dan Barry on finding stories, his central purpose and how he ends the work day.
content: Dan Barry has worked as a reporter at The New York Times since 1995. He has written for the Metro, Sports and National desks; his longest running beat here was This Land, an 11-year search for stories across America. Before coming to The Times, he was a reporter at The Providence Journal in Rhode Island, where he shared a Pulitzer Prize for investigating the state’s court system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: The Yankees Aren’t Bad, They Are Ordinary
description: The team views itself as a top contender, and still has its fair share of stars, but the reality is setting in that its payroll and pedigree can’t push it past its rivals.
content: BOSTON — He stood in foul territory down the right field line on Tuesday, back at the scene of his famous home run, long ago on a golden October afternoon. Bucky Dent, 69 years old, silver hair beneath his Yankees cap, had flown in from Florida to see his old team face the Boston Red Sox at Fenway Park with the season at stake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: At Least 4 Injured in Texas High School Shooting, Police Say
description: An 18-year-old student was taken into custody and charged in the shooting at Timberview High School in Arlington, which had been placed on lockdown.
content: A shooting at a high school in Arlington, Texas, on Wednesday left four people injured, including three taken to a hospital, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Vatican Issues Acquittals in Sexual Abuse Case Involving Former Altar Boys
description: One defendant, now a priest, had been accused of sexual abuse when he and his accuser were teenage students at a seminary within the Vatican walls. Another priest was accused of covering it up.
content: VATICAN CITY — A Vatican court on Wednesday acquitted a priest on sexual abuse charges dating to when he and his accuser were teenage altar boys at a seminary within the Vatican walls. A second priest, the rector of the seminary at the time, was cleared of charges that he covered up the alleged abuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Yankees Are Done. A Frustrating Season Ends in a Wild-Card Loss.
description: Yankees starter Gerrit Cole surrendered three runs and exited with no outs in the third inning as the Boston Red Sox advanced to a division series against Tampa Bay.
content: BOSTON — Concluding a 162-game, six-month regular season with one night is both nerve wracking and cruel. But if a team is going to have its year decided by a winner-take-takes-all contest, the best antidote is having its ace, one of the elite starting pitchers in baseball, on the mound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Marie Wilcox, Who Saved Her Native Language From Extinction, Dies at 87
description: The subject of a Times Op-Doc, she was the last fluent speaker of Wukchumni and spent 20 years producing the first complete dictionary of its vocabulary.
content: For many years, Marie Wilcox was the guardian of the Wukchumni language, one of several Indigenous languages that were once common in Central California but have either disappeared or nearly disappeared. She was the only person for a time who could speak it fluently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roddy Lindsay
title: I Designed Algorithms at Facebook. Here’s How to Regulate Them.
description: Fixing how central they are to the platform’s content moderation could be the answer to its woes.
content: Washington was entranced Tuesday by the revelations from Frances Haugen, the Facebook product manager-turned-whistle-blower. But time and again, the public has seen high-profile congressional hearings into the company followed by inaction. For those of us who work at the intersection of technology and policy, there’s little cause for optimism that Washington will turn this latest outrage into legislative action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: A ‘potentially disastrous’ data breach hits Twitch, the livestreaming site.
description: Included in the breach was a list that purportedly showed how much money each of the platform’s streamers had earned in the past two years.
content: Twitch, the live-video site popular with gamers, said on Wednesday that it had endured a data breach that security researchers believe may have provided sweeping insight into the platform’s computer code, security vulnerabilities and payments to its content creators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: How to Fix Facebook
description: This is a pivotal moment in Facebook’s history. Here are suggestions for how to improve the company.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. Here is a collection of past columns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Ben Hubbard
title: Dubai’s Ruler Hacked Phones of His Ex-Wife and Her Lawyers, U.K. Court Says
description: The sheikh, embroiled in a court case with his former wife, a Jordanian princess, used Israeli software to hack the phones. One of the lawyers targeted is a member of Britain’s House of Lords.
content: LONDON — When the hyper-wealthy ruler of the Middle Eastern emirate of Dubai found himself embroiled in a British court case with the Jordanian princess who was once his wife, he did more than hire top-shelf lawyers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan and Lisa Waananen Jones
title: Nebraska restores its Covid data dashboard after taking it down over the summer.
description: Gov. Pete Ricketts said the state’s unusually strict privacy laws  prohibited the continued release of the data after he let an emergency order lapse in June.
content: Tracking community transmission is at the heart of efforts to stop the spread of the coronavirus, scientists say, and in most states the daily dashboards showing new cases have been a critical tool for public health officials trying to track the trajectory of the virus, which has killed 700,000 Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annaliese Griffin
title: Stop Bashing Other Parents for Their Vaccine Choices in Front of Your Kids
description: Don't miss this opportunity to model empathy.
content: If you’ve dipped even a toe into the kiddie pool of modern parenting politics, then you’re probably aware that it’s actually a shark tank. Confess your love for the convenience of school lunches and expect a pitying smile. A far more withering gaze will meet any mention of a Happy Meal or a decision to stop breastfeeding. Making choices for our children often feels like a high-stakes game show in which there is only one right answer and everyone is shouting their own version of it at you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Sex, Drugs and Roller Skates
description: A new book pays tribute to the vanished magic of Flipper’s, a storied if short-lived 1970s skate palace.
content: LOS ANGELES — “Do you want to skate?” Liberty Ross said, opening a door on a closet full of ankle-height quad skates with boots in all sizes and assorted animal patterns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Biden Calls Curbing Filibuster to Raise Debt Limit ‘a Real Possibility’
description: Senate Democrats discussed carving out an exception to the 60-vote requirement as they explore ways to overcome Republican opposition.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden said on Tuesday that Democrats are considering a change to Senate filibuster rules to bypass a Republican blockade over raising the debt limit, which has set the United States on a collision course with a government default.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Facebook Outage
description: How were you and the people you know affected when Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp were inaccessible for hours this week?
content: “Facebook and its family of apps, including Instagram and WhatsApp, were inaccessible for hours on Monday, taking out a vital communications platform used by billions and showcasing just how dependent the world has become on a company that is under intense scrutiny,” writes The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo
title: Aberdeen, N.J.: Reasonably Priced Housing Not Far From the Beach
description: The Monmouth County township offers an affordable alternative to nearby areas, with proximity to major highways and to the water.
content: Josh Naparstek spent his childhood living in the A section of Strathmore, a neighborhood in Aberdeen, N.J. Now grown and married, Mr. Naparstek, 33, a tech solutions consultant, recently moved into the W section.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniela J. Lamas
title: ‘You’re Dying,’ I Told My Patient. I Wish I Hadn’t.
description: Why a patient in denial is such a challenge for doctors.
content: My patient’s chart was brief. A diagnosis of colon cancer that might have been cured had he not disappeared from medical care to return, nearly a year later, with cancer so advanced that it had torn through his intestines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Want to Be a City Commissioner? It Helps to Be Friendly With the Mayor.
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio has appointed allies who worked on his past campaigns to head New York City agencies, despite their having little relevant experience.
content: Faced with half a dozen major vacancies during his eighth and final year in office, Mayor Bill de Blasio had what appeared to be a simple choice: promote an experienced hand from within, or persuade an outsider to sign on for what was likely to be a very temporary job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Mic Reboots Itself, With More Pop Culture Coverage and Less Politics
description: Under new ownership, the online publication aimed at younger readers unveiled a revamped version of itself on Wednesday.
content: Mic, an online magazine that was known for an earnest mix of political news and opinion essays aimed at millennial readers on the left, has rebooted itself under new ownership as a more varied publication, with a dash of 1970s-era Rolling Stone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: New Top Federal Prosecutors in Manhattan and Brooklyn Are Confirmed
description: One of the two, Damian Williams, will be the first Black person to lead the powerful U.S. attorney’s office for New York’s Southern District.
content: The U.S. Senate confirmed Damian Williams late Tuesday as the new U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York, the office of Senator Chuck Schumer said, making Mr. Williams the first African American to lead one of the nation’s most powerful federal prosecutor’s offices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Skateboarding’s Cardinal Rule: Dare to Be You’
description: In this lesson, students will explore how skateboarding celebrates individualism and builds community. Then they will describe and document what community looks like in their lives.
content: This lesson is a part of our new Accessible Activities feature, which aims to welcome a wider variety of learners to our site and to The Times in general. Learn more and tell us what you think here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Discovery of ‘Bulk Marijuana’ Preceded Tucson Train Shooting, U.S. Says
description: Investigators say they found more than five pounds of marijuana and 50 packages of edibles before one of the suspects opened fire on federal agents in Arizona.
content: First, came a tip. Then, not so discreetly, investigators say, an Amtrak passenger stowed three bags in another row and returned to his seat just as drug enforcement agents boarded a crowded train on Monday morning during a stop in Tucson, Ariz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: ‘We All Know Where We Came From’
description: The Chicago White Sox have fully embraced a clubhouse culture led by a large group of Latino players. The support, along with the love, has helped power the team’s ascent.
content: CHICAGO — Scan the Chicago White Sox lineup on any given day over the past two seasons, and it looks like Latin America. There are Cuban players at catcher, first base, third and center field. Since late July, a Venezuelan has been handling second base. A Dominican patrols left field, and other Dominicans have served as the designated hitter at various points.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Clint and Ron Howard Remember When They Were Just ‘The Boys’
description: In a new memoir, the showbiz siblings recall their experiences growing up on “The Andy Griffith Show,” “Star Trek” and other Hollywood classics. But they weren’t all happy days.
content: Growing up, Clint and Ron Howard never had to dream of stardom, because as children they’d already achieved it. Ron was just 6 when he was second-billed on “The Andy Griffith Show” and 8 when “The Music Man,” featuring him crooning “Gary, Indiana,” was released. Clint, his younger brother, was racking up roles on “Bonanza,” “Star Trek” and “Gentle Ben.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: New Zealand will hold an ‘Election Day’-style vaccination event.
description: The hope, for a single Saturday, amounts to vaccinating about one in 12 of those eligible for a shot, and one in 15 of the total population.
content: New Zealand hopes to vaccinate as many as 350,000 people in a single day next week, the country’s largest Covid inoculation effort to date, as it pushes closer to reopening its economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Trudeau sets deadlines for employees of Canada’s federal government to be vaccinated.
description: “It’s very simple,” the prime minister said. “If you want to continue to work for the public service of Canada you need to be fully vaccinated.”
content: Canada will make vaccination mandatory as of the end of October for air and rail passengers, and as of Oct. 29 for federal government workers, including members of the military and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: You Got Lost and Had to Be Rescued. Should You Pay?
description: The coronavirus pandemic sent a surge of inexperienced hikers into the wilderness. Many ran into trouble. Now states are looking to bill them for costly search and rescue operations.
content: It was 11 p.m. one night last July when a couple realized they would not make it back down the Old Bridle Path. They were with their two children just over a mile into the hiking trail on Mount Lafayette, roughly 70 miles north of Concord, N.H.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Only a fraction of U.S. health care workers are risking their jobs over vaccinations.
description: Large health care systems around the country say that a very small percentage of their workers have missed vaccination deadlines.
content: With deadlines for health care workers to get coronavirus vaccinations either in the past or quickly approaching, it is clear that only a fraction of those workers across the nation are choosing to risk their jobs by failing to comply.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Researchers find a higher than expected risk of myocarditis in young men after full vaccination.
description: Males between 16 and 29 years of age have an increased risk of developing heart problems after receiving a second dose of coronavirus vaccines made by Pfizer-BioNtech or Moderna, according to a large new analysis published on Wednesday in the New England Journal of Medicine.
content: Males between 16 and 29 years of age have an increased risk of developing heart problems after receiving a second dose of coronavirus vaccines made by Pfizer-BioNtech or Moderna, according to a large new analysis published on Wednesday in the New England Journal of Medicine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: How the ‘Succession’ Star Nicholas Braun Elevates Cousin Greg
description: On the cutthroat HBO comedy-drama, which returns Oct. 17, Braun and his hopelessly unprepared alter ego are thriving.
content: The big man had come to Little Island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: Anatomy of a Monique Lhuillier Gown
description: On this, the designer’s 25th anniversary year, she breaks down her process, from sourcing the lace to landing the hand-finished product in the hands of the bride.
content: Before she started her label in 1996, Monique Lhuillier was just a woman shopping for a wedding gown. Unsatisfied with her options, and armed with a degree from the Fashion Institute of Design & Merchandising in Los Angeles, Calif., she started designing them herself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Germany Sets Aside an Additional $767 Million for Holocaust Survivors, Officials Say
description: Many of those now eligible for reparations are Russian Jews who survived the Nazi siege of Leningrad. They will receive annual pensions of about $5,200, or 4,500 euros.
content: It’s been 80 years since Nazi soldiers laid siege to the city of Leningrad, Russia, during the Holocaust, but memories of the desperation haven’t faded away for Russian Jews like Raisa Khusid, who survived starvation and bombardment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Sunday Routines, Highway Lines, Unplugging and More
description: Each week we spotlight five accessible activities for a broad range of readers and writers based on reporting in The New York Times.
content: Each Wednesday we shine a spotlight on five student activities that support a broad range of learners. In this week’s roundup of accessible activities, we invite students to think about their relationship with technology, appreciate underappreciated jobs, reflect on their Sunday routines, look closely at a photograph and take a short quiz about Jamaica.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: How Word Lists Help — or Hurt — Crossword Puzzles
description: A look into how the words get chosen for the New York Times Crossword.
content: If we were to go by the New York Times Crossword, Lake ERIE would be the most dazzling body of water on Earth. Mining ORE would be the most lucrative business venture. According to xwordinfo.com, ERIE is the third most popular word in the New York Times Crossword. It has appeared over 1,350 times. ORE is seventh, with over 1,200 appearances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Tyler Adams Is the Captain Now
description: The RB Leipzig star is too young to be stained by the U.S.’s failure to qualify for the last World Cup. But he is old enough to know it is his job to make it right.
content: The age of Tyler Adams is a matter of perspective. In a strict, chronological sense, of course, he is 22 years 8 months, but what that means — whether it is young, as it appears to be, or old, as odd as that seems — depends on the context. There are times, in fact, when even Adams finds it hard to date himself with any degree of accuracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: ‘We’re not out of danger’: A threat lingers even as new U.S. cases and deaths decline.
description: A drop in cases is especially stark in some Southern states, including Florida and Louisiana. But low vaccination rates in some places leave the country vulnerable.
content: New coronavirus cases, hospitalizations and deaths are falling as the United States begins to recover from a persistent summer surge that strained hospitals across the country and killed over 100,000 Americans in just three and a half months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: ‘Sex Education’ Gets More Inclusive in Its Intimacy
description: With its new nonbinary characters and its scenes depicting chest binding and disabled intimacy, the British teen comedy-drama continues to widen its lens.
content: Layla (Robyn Holdaway) slides a bin in front of the bedroom door, takes a small wicker box from its hiding place in a drawer full of clothes and opens it to reveal a roll of Ace bandages and a tin of safety pins.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Cities Reinventing Public Transit
description: Greener transportation is one of the keys to slowing climate change, and that means more than electric cars. Here’s how several cities are starting to electrify mass transit.
content: We’ve been reading a lot about electric cars lately, for good reason. But that made me wonder: What does the future look like for billions of people around the world who can’t afford to buy an electric car — or a car period?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor LaValle
title: It’s a ‘Full-Contact’ Haunted House. What Could Go Wrong?
description: James Han Mattson’s “Reprieve” is a horror novel with questions of identity and power at its core.
content: REPRIEVEBy James Han Mattson
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From Famous Manuscripts to a Bookstore in Egypt
description: A selection of books published this week.
content: SHOUTIN’ IN THE FIRE: An American Epistle, by Dante Stewart. (Convergent, $25.) A theologian reflects on race and religion in America, writing about his experiences in largely white spaces at Clemson University and at an evangelical church in Augusta, Ga.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Biden and Xi Jinping of China Agree to Hold a Virtual Summit
description: The agreement is a recognition of the dangers of going a year into a presidential term without a formal meeting between the leaders of the world’s two largest economies.
content: President Biden will meet President Xi Jinping of China for their first summit by the end of this year — but virtually, not in person, a concession to a pandemic era and a recognition of the dangers of going an entire year into a new presidential term without a formal meeting between the leaders of the world’s largest and second-largest economies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: The White House says it will spend $1 billion to increase the supply of rapid at-home tests.
description: Tests producing results in 15 minutes have been on the market for months, but they have been in short supply in the United States.
content: The White House on Wednesday announced a billion-dollar investment in at-home rapid coronavirus tests that it said would help quadruple their availability by later this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Major Obstacle Removed in Saudi Bid for Premier League Team
description: The end of a piracy dispute involving the Premier League broadcaster beIN Sports could clear the way for a Saudi-led group to buy Newcastle United.
content: LONDON — Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund moved closer to acquiring a Premier League soccer team after the kingdom reached an agreement that resolved the league’s biggest objection to a proposed sale of Newcastle United.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Exercise May Help to Ease ‘Chemo Brain’
description: Women undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer who stayed physically active had fewer problems with memory and thinking.
content: Regular exercise may help lessen “chemo brain” among women being treated for breast cancer, according to a large-scale new study of the associations between physical activity, chemotherapy and cognition. The study, which involved more than 500 women with breast cancer, finds that those who were the most active before, during or after their treatment were the least likely to develop the memory decline and foggy thinking that characterize chemo brain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Brazen Is the Order of the Day at Facebook
description: But how long can we wait for action against the social media company?
content: Would I like to write about anything else in tech except Facebook? I would. Can I write about anything else in tech but Facebook? I cannot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Morales
title: Cimafunk’s Quest to Create One Nación Under a Groove
description: The Cuban musician’s new album, “El Alimento,” is a fresh take on funk that blends Afro-Cuban and African American rhythms using a cast of international collaborators.
content: A few months ago in a Tallahassee, Fla., recording studio, the Cuban vocalist and composer Cimafunk was engaged in a climactic meeting of the minds with the Parliament-Funkadelic leader George Clinton when they stumbled on a fascinating connection between African American and Afro-Cuban music.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: An Asylum-Seeker’s Wrenching Decision: Stay on the Run or Save His Child’s Life?
description: As a humanitarian crisis grows on Poland’s border, where the government has taken a hard line on migrants, one father had to decide whether to save an ailing baby girl and risk being expelled.
content: ALONG THE EASTERN POLAND BORDER — The father had walked in circles in the rain-drenched Polish forest, cradling his sick daughter, delirious after three days with barely any food or water as temperatures dipped toward freezing. He was soaked, shivering and facing a terrible choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Their Downtown Hits Are Now Sharing a Broadway Stage
description: Tina Satter’s “Is This a Room” and Lucas Hnath’s “Dana H.” are performing in rotation at the Lyceum. They spoke about the significance of telling the true stories of living people.
content: The director Tina Satter was just hours from the first preview of her first Broadway show when she popped upstairs for an interview in the most conducive available spot: a box, house right, overlooking the Lyceum Theater stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Emily Cochrane
title: Senate Nears Agreement to Stave Off Debt Crisis Until December
description: With a default on federal debt as little as 12 days away, Senator Mitch McConnell offered to let Democrats temporarily lift the borrowing limit.
content: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats and Republicans neared agreement as they met into the early morning hours Thursday to temporarily pull the nation from the brink of a debt default. The deal would punt their showdown on raising the federal borrowing limit to December after Republicans bowed to pressure to stave off immediate fiscal calamity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr and Cecilia Kang
title: A Star Corporate Lawyer Now Set to Take On Corporate America
description: How Jonathan Kanter, the Biden administration’s choice to be the Justice Department’s antitrust chief, became a progressive foe of Big Tech.
content: Jonathan Kanter is an unlikely economic populist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shashank Bengali
title: A federal study finds that vaccines are preventing large numbers of deaths among U.S. seniors.
description: Covid-19 vaccinations helped prevent tens of thousands of hospitalizations and deaths among older people in the United States in the first five months of this year, according to a new federal study of Medicare recipients.
content: Covid-19 vaccinations helped prevent tens of thousands of hospitalizations and deaths among older people in the United States in the first five months of this year, according to a new federal study of Medicare recipients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Bubba Wallace Is Ebullient, Defiant and Comfortable
description: After his breakthrough win in NASCAR’s top series, only the second such victory by a Black driver at that level, Wallace talked about learning to shut out ugly noise and to focus on what matters most.
content: Bubba Wallace’s fiancée, Amanda Carter, supplied the positivity. Their Aussiedoodle, Asher, brought the joy. Denny Hamlin and Michael Jordan put Wallace in a fast car, and on Monday he joined Wendell Scott, becoming the second Black driver to win a race at NASCAR’s highest level.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: What’s Next for SoHo?
description: The pandemic has left SoHo the hardest-hit commercial district in the hardest-hit city, at least in the United States.
content: It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at SoHo as an indicator of economic damage to retailing and real estate in the pandemic. We’ll also splash around in a new pool in the Bronx.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Indian Health Service ‘Willfully Ignored’ Sexual Abuse by Doctor, Report Finds
description: The independent inquiry, kept private until now, says agency leaders feared that addressing accusations of misconduct by a pediatrician would be ‘awkward.’
content: WASHINGTON — An independent report commissioned by the Indian Health Service found that officials at the federal agency silenced and punished whistle-blowers in an effort to protect a doctor who sexually abused boys on several Native American reservations for decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Léontine Gallois
title: A Climate Activist Walked in the Louis Vuitton Fashion Show
description: It wasn’t the first time a protester has appeared at Paris Fashion Week, and the environmental organization Extinction Rebellion says it won’t be the last.
content: PARIS — A climate activist, bearing a white banner with the words “Overconsumption = Extinction” in bold block lettering, joined the models on the runway for the Louis Vuitton show at the Louvre museum, the final event of Paris Fashion Week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Search for a Covid Test
description: Rapid tests will soon be more available in the U.S.
content: I tried to buy a rapid at-home Covid test yesterday, and the search did not go well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Finance Executives Say Risk of Default Is Already Damaging the Economy
description: Shortly after the C.E.O.s met with President Biden, Senator Mitch McConnell said he would allow Democrats to raise the debt ceiling enough to push a potential default to December.
content: President Biden met with finance executives on Wednesday as he continued to try to put maximum pressure on Senate Republicans to raise the debt ceiling before Oct. 18, the date the Treasury Department has said the United States would go into default.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘There’s Someone Inside Your House’ Review: Problematic Secrets Exposed
description: This horror movie from Netflix is a muddled marriage of progressive politics and retrograde style.
content: Commendably diverse and deplorably unscary, Patrick Brice’s teen-slasher movie, “There’s Someone Inside Your House,” attempts to both update and bow to a genre that peaked decades ago. But in trying to have it both ways, Brice has created a messy, overstuffed parody of moral policing that squanders the promise of its cleverly executed opening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: Lindy Hopping Into the Present With Caleb Teicher and Co.
description: In “Sw!ng Out,” Teicher and a creative team bring vernacular dance to the Joyce. Tacked onto the end? A jam for all.
content: Dancers possess agility of both the body and the mind, but the dance artists behind “Sw!ng Out” are especially brimming over with it. Improvisation, for the most part, is what guides them along, giving them chances to live on the edge and, in turn, to generate a different program each night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: As the debt default looms, the White House warns of financial crisis.
description: ‘A default would send shock waves through global financial markets,’ officials at the White House Council of Economic Advisers warned.
content: As Washington dickers over raising the debt limit, the White House is offering a sober take on the real-world impact of default.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: What the Debt Ceiling Means for Social Security and More
description: The Treasury secretary says the government will run out of money to spend if Congress doesn’t raise the debt ceiling. Here’s what that could mean for programs that help millions of Americans.
content: The federal government is about two weeks away from being unable to pay its bills — and that could delay benefit payments to tens of millions of retirees, Medicare and Medicaid providers, and numerous others receiving checks from the U.S. Treasury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Texas Man Is Sentenced to 15 Months for Online Covid-19 Hoax
description: Christopher Charles Perez, 40, wrote on Facebook last year that he had paid someone who was infected with the coronavirus to lick groceries at a San Antonio supermarket, federal prosecutors said.
content: On April 5, 2020, Christopher Charles Perez posted a message on Facebook about an H-E-B grocery store in San Antonio, federal prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: How to watch tonight’s game.
description: First pitch of the Cardinals-Dodgers game is scheduled for 8:10 p.m. Eastern time.
content: One came into the season as the defending champion and the betting favorite to repeat. The other wasn’t a lock for the playoffs until the final weeks of the season. But two storied National League franchises, which have combined for an eye-popping 18 World Series titles, will face off in a wild-card game that will propel one of them to a league division series and will send the other home licking its wounds and wondering what might have been.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Dana Rubinstein
title: Bill de Blasio Thinks He Could Be Governor. Does Anyone Else?
description: A run for higher office by New York City’s mayor might be viewed skeptically across the state, but he says he wants to remain in public life.
content: Mayor Bill de Blasio has begun to tell people privately that he plans to run for governor of New York next year, according to three people with direct knowledge of his conversations with fellow Democrats and donors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: A Trial About Wealth, Privilege and the Murkiness of College Admissions
description: In closing arguments at the Varsity Blues trial, prosecutors focused on bribes, but the ways in which universities cater to rich families are also on trial.
content: As lawyers gave their closing arguments in the first trial of the college admissions scandal on Wednesday, a question hung over the Boston courtroom: Will the jury, in a city where town-and-gown suspicion can be strong, see the trial as a tale of a flawed, possibly corrupt college admissions system, or of the arrogance and immorality of wealthy men?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Break the Fourth Wall
description: Jules Markey’s puzzle is for the birds.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — It’s a welcome return for Jules Markey, who’s making his 22nd appearance in the New York Times Crossword! This one was pretty tricky for a Wednesday, in my view, between a higher-than-average number of clues I’d classify as “tricky” and another element you might more commonly expect to find on a Thursday (more on that below).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: As inexperienced hikers hit the wilderness during the pandemic, some states bill them for the cost of rescues.
description: The pandemic has led to a surge of inexperienced hikers venturing into the outdoors, and that in turn has increased the pressure on search-and-rescue teams, as well as the costs.
content: The pandemic has led to a surge of inexperienced hikers venturing into the outdoors, and that in turn has increased the pressure on search-and-rescue teams, as well as the costs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: A Big Hollywood Premiere That Was a Long Time Coming
description: The Academy Museum of Motion Pictures was over budget and years behind schedule, and some feared it would be a flop. Its new director, Bill Kramer, helped get it back on track.
content: Two years ago, the Academy Museum of Motion Pictures had all the trappings of a full-fledged Hollywood disaster in the making. It was over budget and behind schedule. Amid the delays and a contentious debate about the museum’s mission and purpose, it parted ways with its founding director, and the museum board reached across the country to bring back its former fund-raising chief, Bill Kramer, to rescue a project that now threatened to tarnish an already beleaguered Academy. Then the pandemic hit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Barry Diller’s Dotdash Agrees to Buy Meredith, a Magazine Giant
description: People, InStyle, Entertainment Weekly and more than 40 other magazines would become part of the same company as Serious Eats and Investopedia.
content: A digital-age magazine giant was born on Wednesday with the announcement that Dotdash, a publishing unit of Barry Diller’s InterActiveCorp, had reached an agreement to acquire Meredith, the publisher of People, Better Homes & Gardens, InStyle, Entertainment Weekly and roughly 40 other titles and digital brands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: How to Grow Figs in a Cold Climate
description: It may not be easy — but it isn’t impossible, either.
content: It looked like the best fig year ever, with maybe 20 fruits forming on my potted tree as the season progressed. But frost is coming any day, and many of those figs are still hanging there, undersized and hard and green, destined never to achieve ripeness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Los Angeles requires proof of vaccination to enter many businesses, one of the nation’s strictest rules.
description: Expanded inoculation requirements in workplaces and crowded public spaces have spurred vaccination rates in parts of the country.
content: Los Angeles will require most people to provide proof of full coronavirus vaccination to enter a range of indoor businesses, including restaurants, gyms, museums, movie theaters and salons, in one of the nation’s strictest vaccine rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: The choice for a Colorado patient: Get vaccinated, or miss out on a kidney transplant.
description: A hospital system said she would be inactivated on the waiting list for “noncompliance” because she had not received a Covid inoculation.
content: A Colorado health system told a prospective kidney transplant recipient that she would not receive an organ donation if she remained unvaccinated against the coronavirus, a state lawmaker said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Fat Bear Week: 480 Otis Takes Title for 4th Time
description: The brown bear was named the winner of the annual contest in which people vote for their favorite chunky bear at Katmai National Park and Preserve in Alaska.
content: Move over Bear 747. In the battle of the bulkiest bear in Alaska, there’s a new heavyweight champion at Katmai National Park and Preserve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Administration to Restore Climate Criteria to Landmark Environmental Law
description: A proposed rule would require agencies to study the climate impacts of new highways, pipelines and other projects, reversing a Trump-era effort to weaken reviews.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Wednesday announced that it would restore climate change protections to the nation’s bedrock environmental law, the National Environmental Policy Act, which former President Donald J. Trump had weakened in an effort to speed the approval of projects like mines, pipelines, dams and highways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: When Listening to a Book Is Better Than Reading It
description: Audiobooks aren’t a cheap shortcut to reading. Sometimes they elevate a book beyond its text alone.
content: Over the past few years, I have been obsessed with the work of the Australian novelist Liane Moriarty. Yes, me and everyone else. Ever since her 2014 blockbuster, “Big Little Lies,” Moriarty has become one of the publishing industry’s most dependable hitmakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Trump True Believers Have Their Reasons
description: One third of Americans still think Biden’s victory in 2020 was illegitimate. What gives?
content: Just who believes the claim that Donald Trump won in 2020 and that the election was stolen from him? Who are these tens of millions of Americans, and what draws them into this web of delusion?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert O'Connell
title: N.F.L. Punters Face a Perfect Pickle
description: With fewer teams opting to punt than ever, punters face more pressure to be flawless. Anything less can produce a different sort of spiral.
content: One morning last December, Michael Dickson, the Seattle Seahawks’ punter, sat on the floor of his home and meditated. He slowed his breath and wiped his mind clean. He didn’t think of that afternoon’s matchup with the division rival Los Angeles Rams, or the fact that, if the Seahawks won, they would secure the N.F.C. West title. He didn’t think of anything at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Australia to Shift All Offshore Processing of Migrants to Island Nation of Nauru
description: Australia will stop processing asylum-seekers at offshore detention centers in Papua New Guinea, which have been criticized by human rights groups, but will continue handling them on the island of Nauru.
content: Australia said Wednesday that it would stop processing asylum-seekers at offshore detention centers in Papua New Guinea, which have been criticized by human rights groups, by the end of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Is Your School Facing Shortages Because of the Pandemic?
description: Schools around the country are struggling to find bus drivers, teachers and even food for school lunches. Have you experienced this at your school?
content: As schools return to in-person learning, many are experiencing shortages, which means they don’t have enough of something. In a recent New York Times article, the writer Giulia Heyward describes some of them:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: Is Moviegoing Undemocratic?
description: The plan to distribute the art-house film “Memoria” in one theater at a time has set off a heated debate over whether the idea is elitist or inspired.
content: I saw “Memoria” during the New York Film Festival, projected on a screen in a room somewhere other than my house. It’s a strange, captivating movie, graceful and elusive, with a distinctive pedigree. Starring Tilda Swinton and directed by Apichatpong Weerasethakul, who is from Thailand, “Memoria” was shot in Colombia and will be that country’s official selection for the Academy Awards. At once emotionally resonant and tricky to describe, it’s the kind of challenging movie that critics embrace in the hope that it might find an audience beyond the festival circuit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Kornei
title: How Maori Arrival in New Zealand Was Frozen in Antarctic Ice
description: Ice cores drilled from the southern continent preserved a signal of the peopling of islands thousands of miles away.
content: When it comes to records of human history, don’t overlook Earth’s only uninhabited continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: A New Vaccine Strategy for Children: Just One Dose, for Now
description: Myocarditis, a rare side effect, occurs mostly after the second dose. So in some countries, officials are trying out single doses for children.
content: Even as parents in the United States wrestle with difficult questions over vaccinating their children against the coronavirus, families in other countries have been offered a novel option: giving children just one dose of the vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: It’s Time to Stop Paying for a VPN
description: Many virtual private network services that were meant to protect your web browsing can no longer be trusted. Here are other ways.
content: I’m done with paying for a virtual private network, a service that claims to protect your privacy when you’re connected to a public Wi-Fi network at the local coffee shop, the airport or a hotel.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Ex-Insider Says Facebook Hid Efforts to Hook Users
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, October 6, 2021.
content: “I’m here today because I believe Facebook’s products harm children, stoke division and weaken our democracy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dorie Greenspan
title: The Haunting Power of Miso-Maple Loaf Cake
description: Sweet enough to be called cake but savory enough to be as good with a slice of Cheddar as it is with the gloss of warm jam spread over its top.
content: After 30 years of having a room in the basement devoted entirely to Lego towns and villages, space stations and parking garages, railroads, trolleys and a few funiculi, my husband and son agreed to pack up all the pieces and replace them with cabinets, shelves and a big worktable, which, for the past few months, has been used to support boxes of my old notebooks that were recently excavated. Some of the books have stories that go on for pages, and others have just a word here, nothing for a while and then another word farther on. They’re fragments from every part of my adult life, not journals — they’re too disjointed to be called that — but vignettes that often spark a memory and sometimes don’t. I’m sure that the notebooks I now keep at the ready everywhere in the house will soon resemble the old ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: ‘Black No More’ to Land Off Broadway This Winter
description: The musical will feature the theatrical debut of the Roots’ Black Thought, who will be writing the music and lyrics and be in a lead role.
content: “Black No More,” a musical with a book by the “12 Years a Slave” screenwriter John Ridley and music and lyrics by the Roots’ Tariq Trotter, a.k.a. Black Thought, will finally get its turn in the spotlight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘V/H/S/94’ Review: The Right Snuff
description: This lo-fi horror omnibus is a grisly, gory gem.
content: “V/H/S” is a series of found-footage horror anthologies whose constituent shorts are made to seem like the contents of old, and possibly haunted, videocassettes. The problem to date has been that, like most omnibus films, the quality of the segments ranges wildly, so that the odd effective short winds up sandwiched between shorts that are decidedly second-rate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: The first ever malaria vaccine.
content: The World Health Organization endorsed the first ever vaccine to prevent malaria, a disease that kills about 500,000 people each year, including hundreds of thousands of African children under the age of 5.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Lessons from Sweden’s pandemic experiment.
content: Throughout the pandemic, Sweden has taken its own path.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley and Erica L. Green
title: Troubled Student Loan Forgiveness Program Gets an Overhaul
description: The sweeping changes will help more than a half-million public service workers who had thought they were paying down their debt for years.
content: The Biden administration is overhauling a student loan forgiveness program for public service employees that had become a notorious quagmire, introducing a sweeping set of fixes on Wednesday that Education Department officials said would help more than half a million people get closer to the relief they had been denied for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: YouTube Deletes Two R. Kelly Channels, but Stops Short of a Ban
description: The video platform said it was enforcing its terms of service, one week after the singer was convicted on federal racketeering and sex trafficking charges.
content: A week after R. Kelly’s conviction on federal racketeering and sex trafficking charges, YouTube has deleted two of the R&B star’s official video channels, but is not banning his music entirely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Simonson
title: Bad News for Bourbon Lovers: No George T. Stagg in 2021
description: The Buffalo Trace Distillery says barrels of the cult favorite whiskey produced in 2006 did not live up to its standards.
content: Among bourbon enthusiasts, the annual release of George T. Stagg, a barrel-proof, unfiltered bourbon produced by Buffalo Trace Distillery in Kentucky, is a big event. Fans typically pay many times the suggested retail price of $99 — if they can find a bottle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: China is Rocked by Uncertainty. Why is Wall Street Bullish?
description: Beijing is opening its financial system to foreign banks — and they have maintained their traditional openness to the Communist Party’s rule.
content: This year has been unsettling for Chinese business. The ruling Communist Party has gone after the private sector industry by industry. The stock markets have taken a huge hit. The country’s biggest property developer is on the verge of collapse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Facebook Hearing Strengthens Calls for Regulation in Europe
description: A whistle-blower who told Congress about the tech giant’s inner workings has spoken with top policymakers in Brussels, Britain and France about the need for tougher oversight.
content: LONDON — The congressional testimony from the Facebook whistle-blower, Frances Haugen, has intensified calls in Europe for new regulations aimed at the social media company and other Silicon Valley giants, proposals considered by many to be among the most stringent and far-reaching in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Vandals Tag 9 Barracks at Auschwitz With Antisemitic Slurs
description: The police and the Auschwitz Memorial are urging anyone with knowledge of the vandalism to come forward.
content: Vandals sprayed antisemitic slogans and phrases denying the Holocaust in English and German on nine wooden barracks at the Auschwitz-Birkenau memorial site, in what officials there called “an outrageous attack on the symbol of one of the greatest tragedies in human history.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: G.M. Hopes Electric Cars and New Businesses Will Help Double Its Revenue
description: G.M. said it would develop ride-hailing services that use autonomous cars, create insurance products and expand its defense contracting work.
content: WARREN, Mich. — General Motors has been spending billions of dollars in the last few years to electrify its cars and trucks, as it tries to catch up to Tesla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Precious Fondren
title: Amid Conflicting Accounts, Tourists Plead Not Guilty in Carmine’s Fight
description: Three Texas tourists were arraigned on assault and harassment charges, weeks after an altercation at an Upper West Side restaurant drew widespread attention.
content: Three women who were involved in an altercation with a hostess at a popular Italian restaurant on the Upper West Side were arraigned this week on assault and harassment charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: noxious
description: This word has appeared in 70 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Boris Johnson Pledges Transformed Economy for U.K.
description: The prime minister sketched a vision of Britain on the cusp of change, but barely mentioned the spate of fuel and food shortages that have afflicted the country in recent weeks.
content: MANCHESTER, England — Declaring that Britain would not return to the “broken model” of the past, Prime Minister Boris Johnson vowed on Wednesday to engineer a radical transformation of the country’s economy to a future defined by highly skilled workers earning higher wages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Spoils Stephanie Grisham’s Tell-All Tidbits
description: Colbert joked that the former White House press secretary had titled her Trump tell-all “I Just Recently Grew a Spine.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: James Bond Saved the World, but Can He Rescue U.K. Movie Theaters?
description: The 25th installment of the Bond franchise has brought record-breaking numbers of people back to British movie theaters, but pressures on the industry continue.
content: LONDON — By the time the 25th James Bond movie, “No Time to Die,” premiered to an audience of stars, members of the royal family and key workers here last week, it seemed to have the full weight of Britain’s movie theater industry on its shoulders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: In a building in Brooklyn, residents stopped paying rent. Thank the pandemic for their activism.
description: Across New York City, many tenants who lost their jobs after the city went into lockdown are facing millions of dollars in unpaid rent. They’ve been kept in their homes by government aid programs and a state eviction moratorium that expires in January.
content: Across New York City, many tenants who lost their jobs after the city went into lockdown are facing millions of dollars in unpaid rent. They’ve been kept in their homes by government aid programs and a state eviction moratorium that expires in January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: Seen ‘Squid Game’? Watch This Next.
description: Here are six series and films you can stream that share the Netflix hit’s dystopian themes and social commentary.
content: The Korean TV series “Squid Game” has been a sensation since it debuted on Netflix in September. The twisty thriller — about an assortment of desperate debtors who risk their lives in a series of supercharged children’s games, in hopes of winning a big cash prize — has hooked audiences with its fantastical sets and costumes, its cliffhanger-heavy plotting and its pointed commentaries on human nature and class struggle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Justices Make a Surprising Proposal in Torture Case
description: Twenty years after the Sept. 11 attacks, three justices said it was time to hear from the first detainee subjected to brutal interrogation by the C.I.A.
content: WASHINGTON — Twenty years after the Sept. 11 attacks, the Supreme Court on Wednesday found itself struggling to address two issues stemming from that period: torture and government secrecy. Before the justices were done for the day, the proceedings had taken a surprising turn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Murchie
title: Flipping the Script on the College Essay With Help From The New York Times
description: How one teacher uses personal narratives to help high school seniors write application essays that are “powerful, meaningful and clear”
content: As we kick off a third year of our student narrative writing contest, we bring you an idea from Sharon Murchie, a 10th and 12th grade English teacher at Okemos High School in Okemos, Mich., for how to use personal essays from The Times to help students write meaningful and authentic college application essays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Damning evidence about Facebook products.
content: Frances Haugen, a former Facebook product manager turned whistle-blower, yesterday told a Senate subcommittee how the company deliberately kept people — including children — hooked on its services. She had previously leaked thousands of pages of internal documents to The Wall Street Journal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: If Your Rent Is Going Up, This Episode Is for You
description: How do we fix America’s housing crises?
content: Rent is soaring, but close to two-thirds of renters remain on leases because of financial reasons. In 2019, nearly 70 percent of millennials surveyed said that they could not afford to buy a home on account of rising prices, and the number of people in the United States without shelter has increased by about 30 percent in the past five years. We’re in a housing crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Anderson
title: Laurie Anderson Has a Message for Us Humans
description: For half a century, she has taken the things we know best— our bodies, our rituals, our nation — and shown us how strange they really are.
content: When the Hirshhorn Museum told Laurie Anderson that it wanted to put on a big, lavish retrospective of her work, she said no. For one thing, she was busy. She has been busy now for roughly 50 years, hauling her keyboards and experimental violins all over the world to put on huge bonanzas of lasers and noise loops and incantatory monologues that she delivers in a voice somewhere between slam poetry, an evening newscast, a final confession and a bedtime story. Although Anderson plays multiple instruments, her signature tool has always been her voice. Words emerge from her mouth deliberate and hyperenunciated, surrounded by unpredictable pauses. She piles up phrases the way van Gogh piled up brush strokes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: ‘Covid toes’ may be caused by a powerful immune response, a new study finds.
description: The painful condition often appears in people who test negative for the virus, indicating that their bodies have fought it off.
content: Shortly after the pandemic erupted last year, doctors were baffled by a surge of patients, mostly teenagers and young adults, who came in complaining of chilblains — painful lesions on their toes, and sometimes also on their fingers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Back to the Office, a Protest and a Time Traveler’s Ball
description: Miu Miu and Louis Vuitton bring the ready-to-wear season to a provocative end.
content: PARIS — Around the same time that Frances Haugen, the Facebook whistle-blower, was testifying before Congress about controversial actions by her former employer, the Twitter chief executive Jack Dorsey was in the front row of the Louis Vuitton show, stroking his beard meditatively as he talked to the Vuitton owner, Bernard Arnault, and watching a parade of elaborately embroidered, slightly destroyed evening gowns stretched over quasi-19th century hip panniers. The panniers, which resembled the trays that cigarette girls carried, bounced as they walked. The lights of what looked like hundreds of antique crystal chandeliers twinkled overhead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Hoberman
title: A Master of Mixing and Matching Movies Gets a Citywide Tribute
description: Amos Vogel is considered America’s seminal film programmer. The New York Film Festival and other institutions are paying their respects on his centenary.
content: Inside every movie buff lives a film critic. Inside every critic lives a film programmer. And inside every programmer’s heart is a place for Amos Vogel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Their Thai Cave Rescue Film Was Done. Then 87 Hours of Footage Arrived.
description: For their heart-pounding documentary, Elizabeth Chai Vasarhelyi and Jimmy Chin faced a thorny tangle of rights, permissions and personalities.
content: The documentary filmmaker Elizabeth Chai Vasarhelyi lives in fear of not telling a complete story. What if there is another angle to explore? More footage to uncover? Is her exploration of a topic ever really complete? Those feelings were occupying large swaths of her brain back in May when she was finally able to travel to Thailand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Robert Schiffmann, Inventive Guru of the Microwave, Dies at 86
description: As a scientist he saw the potential of microwave ovens when he observed one heating up a sandwich in the 1960s. Microwaveable oatmeal, among other advances, was in his future.
content: Robert Schiffmann, who first glimpsed a microwave oven in the early 1960s in his job as a scientist for a bakery equipment company before becoming one of the technology’s leading experts, developing products and processes to expand its capabilities, died on Sept. 4 in Wall Township, N.J. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty
title: Two Winter Olympics Underdogs That Have Already Won
description: Actively Black will outfit Team Nigeria at the Games.
content: Lanny Smith, the founder of Actively Black, an athleisure brand, does not take his new partnership with the Nigerian Bobsled and Skeleton Federation lightly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Debt Ceiling Fight Gives Democrats Ammunition Against Filibuster
description: Party leaders say the G.O.P.’s refusal to allow a vote to avert default is the most powerful argument yet for weakening the Senate’s signature procedural weapon.
content: WASHINGTON — Leading Senate Democrats increasingly see the Republican blockade against raising the federal debt limit as clear justification for changing the chamber’s filibuster rule, a long-shot effort that so far has lacked the unanimous support within their ranks it would need to succeed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: Jerome Powell’s Future
description: The Federal Reserve chair’s term expires in February. Though insiders say that he has a good chance of being reappointed, there are growing complications.
content: Jay Powell, the Fed chair, has been praised for how he used the central bank’s powers to steer the economy through the pandemic. His term as chair expires in February, and insiders say that he has a good chance of being reappointed. But the decision is subject to an unusually high level of uncertainty, with growing complications around his renomination, The Times’s Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Why These New Yorkers Stopped Paying Rent
description: The economic crisis caused by the pandemic has placed the city’s housing woes in stark relief. But one group of Brooklyn tenants has been fighting back.
content: It has been years since Patricia Edwards’s top floor apartment in Brooklyn has felt like an acceptable home. When it rains, water leaks into the kitchen and living room. It also pours through a crack in the bathroom ceiling so big that Ms. Edwards needs an umbrella just to use the toilet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: A Guide to Big Changes for Public Service Loan Forgiveness
description: Hundreds of thousands of borrowers with so-called F.F.E.L. student loans, people who paid late and military members could now get credit for years of payments toward erasing their debts.
content: Changes that the Education Department is making to the Public Service Loan Forgiveness Program should help hundreds of thousands qualify for relief much sooner than they had ever hoped — if the alterations work as intended.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Moderna’s vaccine profits propel three new names onto Forbes’s list of the 400 richest Americans.
description: The company’s chairman, a fellow co-founder and an early investor are all listed as multibillionaires.
content: The financial windfall at Moderna, the biotech company behind one of the three federally cleared Covid-19 vaccines, has propelled three new names onto Forbes magazine’s list of the 400 richest people in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Fashion Unites in Tribute to Alber Elbaz
description: Dozens of designers put on a show to honor and celebrate the man and his work.
content: PARIS — When the designer Alber Elbaz, who died from Covid-19 last spring, left his longtime job as creative director of Lanvin in 2015, he didn’t just jump straight into another brand. Instead he took time to explore other industries, meet new people and think about what it was that would make him really happy. He had a lot of ideas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxana Popescu
title: House Hunting in England: Country Living in the Cotswolds for $3 Million
description: The Cotswolds, a bucolic protected landscape running through five English counties, has remained a draw for buyers amid pandemic market shifts.
content: This 6.7-acre property sits at the edge of Longborough, a small village in the heart of the Cotswolds, the rural area in south-central England known for its grassy hills and distinctive Jurassic limestone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Help Us Recommend Children’s Books
description: The Education Briefing is compiling a list of great reads for kids.
content: Readers, we need your help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Moms Are Back to Work, But Child Care Resources Are ‘Laughable’
description: Yearlong waiting lists, babysitters nowhere to be found, and families feeling the strain.
content: Katy Stenta, the pastor of a small church in Albany, N.Y., and the mother of three boys, has experienced pandemic-related child-care shortages from all sides. She helps run a nursery school out of her Presbyterian church, and the newest aide they hired keeps missing work because her child has asthma. Ms. Stenta, 38, has been filling in for her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kasia Pilat
title: 14 Vegetarian Soups and Stews for a Cozy Fall
description: Spend some rewarding time in the kitchen with warming recipes that build up layers and layers of flavor.
content: Maybe you’ve noticed the chill in the air, or that the leaves are starting to turn shades of orange and red. The first pumpkin spice lattes of the season have already been sipped, and perhaps you’ve taken out the sweaters that make you feel like Cameron Diaz courting Jude Law in a cozy cottage in the English countryside. author: By Elizabeth Nelson
title: Do We Really Want Nonstop Action From Football?
description: N.F.L. RedZone and the simulcasts by Peyton and Eli Manning offer up two very modern ways to watch an old sport.
content: “Just keep matriculating that ball down the field, boys!” So went the Hall of Fame coach and broadcaster Hank Stram’s famous malapropism, a directive which meant: In football, you advance on your opponents gradually, with grit and guile, forcing them to yield terrain until you attain the sweet fruit of a field goal or a touchdown. Supposing you don’t know what the word “matriculate” actually means, it makes the entire enterprise sound like a military exhibition; you imagine Hannibal painstakingly matriculating his elephants through Spain and into the shadows of the Roman goal line. For most of its long history, this was how the sport was watched. N.F.L. games run only slightly shorter than awards ceremonies, and sometimes you look outside at a nice autumn Sunday and wonder why you are inside watching four hours of tedium.
